isis.stitle: TSI 04-47-01 - Bus Lower Rub Rail Corrosion Prevention

subjectgroup.subject: Bus Lower Rub Rail Corrosion Prevention

geninfo.para: Bus rub rails have designed drainage holes along the bottom to prevent moisture entrapment behind the rail. In certain applications, dirt and salt plug the drain holes, preventing the moisture from escaping and allowing the build up of a "wet" area behind the rail. Although both sides of the rails have been coated to prevent corrosion, under certain conditions, this area of constant moisture is extremely harsh to the paint and will begin to prematurely deteriorate the metal. In the isolated cases seen, this phenomenon has a tendency to occur on the rear left side of the bus (Figure 1) on two lane roads in states using a Calcium Chloride/Fine Sand combination in road de-icing. It is believed the oncoming passing vehicles cause the deicing mixture to be splashed into the underside of the lower rub rails. The sand will block the drainage holes while the trapped road salt contributes to premature signs of corrosion. Easy regular maintenance prevents this issue from occurring.

svcproc.title: Service Procedure
svcproc.para: Maintenance - During winter months, perform a regular inspection of the lower rub rails, especially the driver's side of the bus. Check for plugged drain holes. Gently use a small wire or narrow screwdriver to remove the sand from the drain hole. Flush rail with fresh water to remove any road salts. If required, brush touch up small scratches with a metal prep solution (e.g., Sikkens Autoprep Etching Pen - from your local Sikkens Jobber or Henkel's Surface Technology's Touch-N-Prep®Alodine®--1132 available online at http://www.buyhstna.com/store) followed by urethane based topcoat paint.
